Android Telephony Reference Manual
YangSongxiang
a22301@motorola.com
2012 Motorola Inc.
This document introduced telephony domain topics on Android platform. It aims to provide a clean, and product-independent reference manual, but should mainly focus on MSM8960.
Android OS version is 4.0(Icecream) and later.
Overview
The whole telephony feature convers at least 3 layers:
App/Framework/Base RIL, which is high layer, as part of Android's source code.
Vendor RIL, which is middle layer, can be proprietary.
Baseband(BP), which is lower layer, usually be QualComm's.
The whole 3 layer composed the telephony feature, on Android system.
framework/base/telephony/ is the upper layer telephony framework, it provides all higer app's services for telephony.
hardware/ril/ is Android's native RIL section, it provides base definition and messages, that communicate with vendor ril. Refer for more details on the native RIL.
The vendor ril and baseband code is totally customerizable, and varies on different products.
High App Layer
Phone Creation
Android uses Factory pattern to manage the phone object's creation. Below is a sample code that PhoneFactory.java create the target phone object:
Code Snippet for Phone Creation public static void makeDefaultPhone(Context context){ int networkMode = Settings.Secure.getInt( Settings.Secure.PREFERRED_NETWORK_MODE); ril = new RIL(xxx, networkMode); Creating RIL based on network type switch(networkMode){ case XXXX: GSMPhone(); case YYYY: CDMAPhone(); } }
Radio State is used indicating current BP Machine status, because phone is definitely power on, of courese.
Thus, the initial radio state should be unavailable, NOT power off, because phone didn't know the BP is on or off, or even not exist at all.
RIL_RadioState
Radio state is defined as RIL_RadioState enum by RIL, and below is it's value:
Radio State Value
Radio ValueNote
RADIO_STATE_OFF(0)Radio explictly powered off (eg CFUN=0)
RADIO_STATE_UNAVAILABLE(1)Unknow state, radio is resetting or others.
RADIO_STATE_ON(10)Radio On.
The radio state legacy value 2~9 is obsolted from Android 4.0.
RIL defined some req/unsol msg for the radio, to help upper layer and lower layer can exchange the radio state correctly:
Radio State Related RIL msg
MsgNote
RIL_REQUEST_RADIO_POWER(23)Toggle radio on and off (for "airplane" mode)
RIL_UNSOL_RESPONSE_RADIO_STATE_CHANGED(1000)Indicate Radio State changed.
Service State Poll
Telephony always keep polling the serivice state(SS), it is the high, user-friendly format, for current mobile phone's service state data.
Each time of a poll cycle, these state values(old V.S. new), were output in RIL log:
GSM Service State Poll in RIL Log D/GSM Poll ServiceState done: oldSS=[..] newSS=[..] oldGprs=.. newGprs=.. oldType=.. newType=.. ... ...
Above old/new value output may varies, as different Android version.
But keep in mind this is high level of a user-view, on service state.
The 1st field of SS, is a ServiceState class instance, it's whole definition can be found in ServiceState::toString(). And it's also a moving target, in different version, and different product(Motorola changing it as well).
Below demo some fields value in the SS
old/newSS fields' value

2roamtrue means Roaming.
3OperatorAlpha LongLong Alpha(such as US AT&T)

App uses VOICE_REGISTRATION_STATE to query current voice registration state. RIL would get this request, and send back the state to app.

FTM and Tools
FTM can be considered as Field Test Menu, or Factory Test Mode. It's usually doing data R/W with BP.
Related tools are RadioComm, RSD, QPST.
RIL Layer
Overall Layout
cover libril in hardware/ dir.
Entry Point of Vendro RIL
The RIL_Init() is entry point in vendor RIL, it's a handshake to exchange each RIL side's function call address, so later we can know how talk to each other.
const RIL_RadioFunctions *RIL_Init(const struct RIL_Env *env, int argc, char **argv);
argc, argv is command option, for more flexible configuration, they are optional.
RIL_RadioFunctions is a function set, return back to Android RIL, to let it know how to send request, how to get current radio state, etc.
RIL_Env is a function set, send in Vendor RIL, tell him if there's any response, unsol msg, etc, how to send them back to Android.
Thus, RIL_Env only contains back-way methods:
struct RIL_Env { void (*OnRequestComplete)(...); void (*OnUnsolicitedResponse)(...); void (*RequestTimedCallback) (...); };

QualComm BP
Telecom Terminology
ESN/MEID/IMEI ESN MEID IMEI
These 3 IDs all identify the mobile phone device.
Electronic Serial Number(ESN), 4-byte(32-bit) value, oldest identify method.
Mobile Equipment IDentifier(MEID), as ESN length is too short, MEID uses longer 7-byte to identify a mobile device. It can be in both hex and dec format, and prefer CDMA.
International Mobile Equipment Identity(IMEI), prefer GSM/UMTS, it only in dec format, using a 15-digit(NOT 15-bit) dec number.
These ID can be found at phone back-side, or press *#06# to show them in the pop-up menu(3gpp protocol). Below is result on Moto Droid2:
Pop-up Menu of MEID(CDMA)
In order to keep back compatibility, ESN/MEID is co-exist in the system. And if ESN is starting with 0x80, it means the MEID is enabled.
For example, the ZTE CDMA phone's pop-up menu would show the dec/hex ESN number, keep MEID be ZERO:
ESN (Hex)A715FE84 (Dec)16701441412 MEID 00000000000000
For thoes GSM/UMTS mode phone, IMEI would prefered, so *#06# pop-up menu would show IMEI instead of MEID, below is result on Moto Milestone:
Pop-up Menu of IMEI(GSM)
QualComm stored above IDs in NV items:
NV Items for ESN/MEID/IMEI
NV IDNotes
NV_ESN_I(0)ESN
NV_MEID_I(1943)MEID
NV_UE_IMEI_I(550)IMEI
MCC/MNC/PLMN
MCC MNC PLMN
These 3 IDs indicating a country's network type.
Mobile Country Code(MCC), 3-digit number, specify a country.
Mobile Netowrk Code(MNC), 2-digit(European) or 3-digit(North America), specify a network operator.
Public Land Mobile Network(PLMN), is MCC+MNC, identify an unique network.
3gpp defines the PLMN number composed by 3-byte:
| 8 | 7 | 6 | 5 | 4 | 3 | 2 | 1 | |===============================================| octet 1 | MCC Digit 2 | MCC Digit 1 | |-----------------------------------------------| octet 2 | MNC Digit 3 | MCC Digit 3 | |-----------------------------------------------| octet 3 | MNC Digit 2 | MNC Digit 1 | |===============================================|
So QualComm code defined it in struct like this:
QualComm PLMN ID definition typedef struct sys_plmn_id_s{ byte identity[3]; } sys_plmn_id_s_type;

AT Commands
For non-single-chip hardware, most of data was exchanged via AT commands. Some of them are 3gpp standard, and some are moto-specific, or QualComm-specific.
Here lists these commands' referenc information.
CIEV
The +CIEV indicates a call(voice, or data)'s connection status. Usually, it's a unsolicit msg, and Moto code uses ~+CIEV to mark as a unsolicit msg.
CIEV
There're totally 3 fields in CIEV:
~+CIEV=calltype,status,reason
The code is in mot_rsl layer, below is the code snippet:

CREG
AT+CREG indicates the registration information, the first 2 fields are most important.
CREG
There're 10-digit value for the +CREG. They had different meaning for GSM and CDMA network.
For GSM, the last 5-digit value are all 0, while CDMA used all fields:
+CREG for CDMA regStatus,RadioTech, baseID, baseLat, baseLong, SID, NID, Roam_Ind,PRL_match, EVDO_rev
+CREG for GSM/UMTS(Last 5-digit are all 0): regStatus,RadioTech,LAC,CID,Rej_cause,0,0,0,0,0
The reference code level can be found at mot_sys:
Code for +CREG mot_at_cmd_status_type mot_sys_at_exec_creg_cmd() { if (mot_rsl_is_cdma_mode()){ sprintf((char*)res_buff_ptr->data_ptr, "%s=%d,%d,%d,%ld,%ld,%d,%d,%d,%d,%d\n", tok_ptr->name, rsl.reg.creg, rsl.sys_mode.camp_mode, rsl.bs.bs_id, bs_lat.s, bs_long.s, rsl.bs.bs_sid, rsl.bs.bs_nid, roam_ind,rsl.reg.prl_match,rsl.sys_mode.evdo_rev ); } else if (mot_rsl_is_gsm_mode()){ sprintf((char*)res_buff_ptr->data_ptr, "%s=%d,%d,%04X,%08lX,%d,0,0,0,0,0\n", tok_ptr->name, rsl.reg.creg, rsl.sys_mode.camp_mode, rsl.ss_info.sys_id.id.plmn_lac.lac, (rsl.ss_info.cell_info.cell_id > 0x7FFFFFFF) ? 0x7FFFFFFF :rsl.ss_info.cell_info.cell_id, rsl.ss_info.reg_reject_info.reject_cause); }
}

RSSI
Received Signal Strength Indication(RSSI) is unsolicit message, indicating the signal strength.
Moto handles it in mot_sys layer, different network type, would result in different fields meaning:
+RSSI Fields Processing in mot_sys void mot_sys_send_rssi() { if (mot_rsl_is_cdma_mode()){ get_rf_power(); sprintf(curr_rssi_cmd, "~+RSSI=%d,%d,%d,%d,%d,%d,%d\n", cdma_bar, cdma_ecio, cdma_rssi, hdr_bar, hdr_sinr, hdr_ec, hdr_ecio); } else if(mot_rsl_is_gsm_mode()){ get_gsm_rf_power(); sprintf(curr_rssi_cmd, "~+RSSI=%d,%d,%d,%d,0,0,0\n", gsm_bar, gsm_rssi, gsm_ber, SIG_BAR_NO_SRV); } }

Call Manager(CM)
NV Items
The NV Items stored most of the BP-related config on the phone. They are specified by numerical number(NV ID), and QualComm uses nv_items_enum_type enum to represent it.
Usually, Motorola extended the nv item, adding own items as well. To avoid conflict, these moto-specific items are began from offset 8000:
nv_items_enum_type
1023 typedef enum { 1024 1025 NV_ESN_I = 0, 1026 NV_ESN_CHKSUM_I = 1, 8205 NV_MAX_I = 7225 8207 #ifdef MOT_FEATURE_MOT_NV 8208 , 8209 MOT_NV_FIRST_I = 8000, 8210 MOT_NV_FIELD_TEST_ENABLE_I = MOT_NV_FIRST_I, 8211 MOT_NV_IN_FACTORY_I = MOT_NV_FIRST_I+1, ... ... } nv_items_enum_type;
core/api/services/nv_items.h is the header defined all the NV items IDs, and their inner data structure.
As so many IDs, and so many different structure for each ID, QualComm combines all these stuff into an union data type, nv_item_type.
QCOM NV Items Info
FieldNotes

Moto Extendstart from offset 8000.
Read/Write NV Items
QualComm allows read/write NV items through diag packet, and it defines a read/write protocol in diag specification.
The read/write action would finally be dispatched to R/W the EFS /nvm/ID data.
The draft logic flow is like this:
+----------+ +----------+ R/W diag req -> | nvdiag.c | --> nvio.c --------> | /nvm/xx/ | +----------+ (EFS API) +----------+
Sometimes, we met the Inactive Items error when read a item, this is usually caused because there's no the NV ID file there, below is a sample code for this case:
Inactive Item Cases nvio_read_item(nv_items_enum_type item, void *data_ptr,){ snprintf(f_name,sizeof(f_name),"/nvm/num/%d",item); if(efs_stat(f_name,&temp_buf) == -1) return NV_NOTACTIVE_S;
status = efs_get(f_name, data_ptr, item_size); return status; }
As QualComm's implementation, there's protection when R/W the nv items. This can be found in below code:
Protection of R/W void *nvdiag_read() { //First check to see if this item is not allowed to be read. //NOTE: These items are unreadable, even if security is unlocked! if (unreadable_nv_item(eItem)) { return( diagpkt_err_rsp( DIAG_BAD_PARM_F, req_pkt, pkt_len )); } } boolean unreadable_nv_item(nv_items_enum_type item) { switch(item){ /* Keys, secrets, and passwords are unreadable */ case NV_A_KEY_I: ... .... case NV_SEC_DEVICE_KEY_I : return true;
default: return false; } }
And furthermore, some NV items' write would require Subsidy Code(SPC) unlock.
Some Comm NV Items Info
The NV Items value can be a flex config file.
For MSM8960(such as Vanquish), there's a fsg partition, and a fsg.mbn image file, which contain the EFS data. Thus loading a new NV data setting would be simple:
$ fastboot flash fsg fsg.mbn
The fsg.mbn file can be extracted by below commands:
Dump the fsg.mbn mkdir temp xxd -s 40 -p fsg.mbn | xxd -r -p - | tar xvf - -C temp xxd temp/nvm/num/8034
All ID-XXX item values are the /nvm/num/ID-XXX files, in binary format.
There're some commonly-used NV items, that MUST be very familiar with them.
BP Panic
The BP Panic is a very huge topic, and always met in product development, especially in bring-up stage.
Panic on MSM8960
First, it supports QualComm's QXDM force panice, which is core dump action of diag extended msg:
Type below commands in QXDM command window:
send_data 75 37 03 00
The 75 37 03 00 is a DIAG payload which indicates:
typedef struct{ uint8 command_code; DIAG_SUBSYS_CMD_F(75) uint8 subsys_id; DIAG_SUBSYS_DEBUG(37) uint16 subsys_cmd_code; ERR_F3_TRACE_CORE_DUMP(0x0003) };
